skills.name: Order negative decimals with a different number of digits
Carry out addition problems involving one negative integer
Use inequality notation to order a negative and a positive integer

explanations.A: I think you have counted down rather than up. You can use a number line to help you.
explanations.C: You are almost there. -16 is the first number that he says, so what is the 5th?
explanations.D: I think you have counted down rather than up. You can use a number line to help you. Don't forget that the first number he says is -16

explanations.A: I think you have counted down rather than up. You can use a number line to help you.
explanations.B: You are almost there. -14 is the first number that he says, so what is the 5th?
explanations.D: I think you have counted down rather than up. You can use a number line to help you. Don't forget that the first number he says is -14

explanations.A: 5 is greater than -6 as it is further up the number line, so this symbol would be correct.
explanations.B: This symbol means less than, but 5 isn't' less than -6. Try drawing out a number line to help you, remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.
explanations.C: This symbol means less than or equal to, but 5 isn't' less than or equal to -6. Try drawing out a number line to help you, remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.
explanations.D: These numbers aren't equal. Try drawing out a number line. Remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.

explanations.A: This symbol means greater than, but -2 isn't greater than 1. Try drawing out a number line, remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.
explanations.B: -2 is less than 1 as it is further down the number line, so we have -2 < 1.
explanations.C: This symbol means greater than or equal to, but -2 isn't greater than or equal to 1. Try drawing out a number line, remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.
explanations.D: These numbers aren't equal. Try drawing out a number line. Remember the numbers get smaller as you go down the number line.

explanations.A: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get 4 is less than or equal to 4. This is true, so the numbers do fit. Try putting the other numbers in the inequality and see if they work.
explanations.B: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get -4 is less than or equal to 4. This is true, so the numbers do fit. Try putting the other numbers in the inequality and see if they work.
explanations.C: If you substitute in the numbers you get 2 is less than or equal to -4. This is not true, so this is the pair that does not fit.
explanations.D: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get -2 is less than or equal to 2. This is true, so the numbers do fit. Try putting the other numbers in the inequality and see if they work.

explanations.A: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get -5 is greater than or equal to -1. This is not true so this is the pair that does not fit.
explanations.B: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get 1 is greater than or equal to -4. This is true. Try putting the other numbers into the inequality to see which one doesn't work.
explanations.C: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get 2 is greater than or equal to 2. This is true. Try putting the other numbers into the inequality to see which one doesn't work.
explanations.D: If you change the d and h for these numbers you get 5 is greater than or equal to 4. This is true. Try putting the other numbers into the inequality to see which one doesn't work.

explanations.A: Not quite. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 2.1, 2.01, 2.105 and 3. Don't forget the place value of these digits
explanations.B: You can find the distance from 0 by looking at just the numbers, and not the negative. That means that -2.01 is closest to 0 as it is only 2 units and 1 hundredth away. All the other numbers are further away because the distances (the positive numbers) are all greater than 2.01.
explanations.C: This one has the most digits, but because of the decimal point it doesn't mean it is the furthest away. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 2.1, 2.01, 2.105 and 3.
explanations.D: This is the number that is furthest away from 0. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 2.1, 2.01, 2.105 and 3.

explanations.A: This is the number that is furthest away from 0. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4, 3.198, 3.02 and 3.2.
explanations.B: This one has the most digits, but because of the decimal point it doesn't mean it is the furthest away. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4, 3.198, 3.02 and 3.2. Don't forget to think about the place value of the digits
explanations.C: You can find the distance from 0 by looking at just the numbers, and not the negative. That means that -3.02 is closest to 0 as it is only 3 units and 2 hundredths away. All the other numbers are further away because the distances (the positive numbers) are all greater than 3.02.
explanations.D: Not quite. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4, 3.198, 3.02 and 3.2. Don't forget to use the place value of the digits.

explanations.A: Almost, you just need to be careful with the place value. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 5.78, 6, 5.8 and 5.7099
explanations.B: This is the one that is furthest away. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 5.78, 6, 5.8 and 5.7099.
explanations.C: Almost, you just need to be careful with the place value of the digits. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 5.78, 6, 5.8 and 5.7099
explanations.D: You can find the distance from 0 by looking at just the numbers, and not the negative. That means that -5.7099 is closest to 0 as it is only 5 units, 7 tenths, 9 hundredths and 9 thousandths away. All the other numbers are further away because the distances (the positive numbers) are all greater than 5.7099

explanations.A: Almost, you just need to be careful with the place value. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4.69, 4.6098, 5 and 4.7
explanations.B: You can find the distance from 0 by looking at just the numbers, and not the negative. That means that -4.6098 is closest to 0 as it is only 4 units, 6 tenths, 9 thousandths and 8 ten thousandths away. All the other numbers are further away because the distances (the positive numbers) are all greater than 4.6098
explanations.C: You have chosen the one that is furthest away. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4.69, 4.6098, 5 and 4.7
explanations.D: Not quite, you need to look at the place value of the digits and not how many there are. If you consider the distance from 0 as the positive of these numbers, you just need to find the smallest from the list 4.69, 4.6098, 5 and 4.7
